title: PBQ: Earned Value Management Calculations
description: Performance-based questions focused on EVM formulas: CPI, SPI, CV, SV, EAC, ETC, VAC, and multi-part scenario calculations. High difficulty.

questions.question: A project has an Earned Value (EV) of $80,000 and an Actual Cost (AC) of $95,000. What is the Cost Variance (CV)? Include the sign and dollar amount (e.g., -5000).
questions.explanation: CV = EV - AC = $80,000 - $95,000 = -$15,000. A negative CV indicates the project is over budget — it has spent $15,000 more than the value of work completed.

questions.question: A project has an Earned Value (EV) of $120,000 and a Planned Value (PV) of $100,000. What is the Schedule Variance (SV)? Include the sign and dollar amount (e.g., 5000).
questions.explanation: SV = EV - PV = $120,000 - $100,000 = $20,000. A positive SV indicates the project is ahead of schedule — more value has been earned than was planned at this point.

questions.question: A project has an Earned Value (EV) of $60,000 and an Actual Cost (AC) of $75,000. What is the Cost Performance Index (CPI)? Round to two decimal places.
questions.explanation: CPI = EV / AC = $60,000 / $75,000 = 0.80. A CPI less than 1.0 means the project is over budget. For every dollar spent, only $0.80 of value is earned.

questions.question: A project has an Earned Value (EV) of $45,000 and a Planned Value (PV) of $50,000. What is the Schedule Performance Index (SPI)? Round to two decimal places.
questions.explanation: SPI = EV / PV = $45,000 / $50,000 = 0.90. An SPI less than 1.0 means the project is behind schedule — only 90% of the planned work has been completed.

questions.question: A project has a BAC of $200,000 and a CPI of 0.80. Assuming the current cost performance trend continues, what is the Estimate at Completion (EAC)? Use the formula EAC = BAC / CPI. Round to the nearest whole dollar.
questions.explanation: EAC = BAC / CPI = $200,000 / 0.80 = $250,000. The project is expected to cost $50,000 more than originally budgeted if the current cost performance trend continues.

questions.question: A project has a BAC of $150,000, an EV of $60,000, and an AC of $70,000. The project manager believes the cost variance was caused by a one-time event and will not recur. What is the EAC using the atypical variance formula? EAC = AC + (BAC - EV).
questions.explanation: EAC = AC + (BAC - EV) = $70,000 + ($150,000 - $60,000) = $70,000 + $90,000 = $160,000. This formula is used when the variance is atypical (a one-time event) and the remaining work is expected to proceed at the budgeted rate.

questions.question: A project has an EAC of $300,000 and an AC of $180,000. What is the Estimate to Complete (ETC)?
questions.explanation: ETC = EAC - AC = $300,000 - $180,000 = $120,000. The ETC represents the expected cost to finish the remaining project work from this point forward.

questions.question: A project has a BAC of $500,000 and an EAC of $575,000. What is the Variance at Completion (VAC)? Include the sign.
questions.explanation: VAC = BAC - EAC = $500,000 - $575,000 = -$75,000. A negative VAC means the project is expected to be over budget by $75,000 when complete.

questions.scenario:
You are the project manager for a network infrastructure upgrade. The project is 50% through its planned duration. Here is the current EVM data:

• Budget at Completion (BAC): $400,000
• Planned Value (PV): $200,000
• Earned Value (EV): $180,000
• Actual Cost (AC): $210,000

parts.question: What is the Cost Variance (CV)? Include the sign.
parts.explanation: CV = EV - AC = $180,000 - $210,000 = -$30,000. The project is $30,000 over budget.

parts.question: What is the Schedule Variance (SV)? Include the sign.
parts.explanation: SV = EV - PV = $180,000 - $200,000 = -$20,000. The project is behind schedule by $20,000 in earned value.

parts.question: What is the CPI? Round to two decimal places.
parts.explanation: CPI = EV / AC = $180,000 / $210,000 ≈ 0.857, rounded to 0.86. The project earns $0.86 in value for every dollar spent.

parts.question: Based on the data, which statement BEST describes the project's status?

options.text: Over budget and ahead of schedule
Under budget and ahead of schedule

parts.explanation: CV is negative (over budget) and SV is negative (behind schedule). CPI < 1 confirms over budget. SPI would also be < 1, confirming behind schedule.

questions.explanation: This scenario tests the core EVM analysis workflow: calculate variances, derive indices, and interpret what they mean for the project. Negative CV = over budget. Negative SV = behind schedule. CPI < 1 = over budget. SPI < 1 = behind schedule.

questions.scenario:
You are managing a mobile application development project with the following data at the end of Month 4:

• Budget at Completion (BAC): $250,000
• Planned Value (PV): $150,000
• Earned Value (EV): $125,000
• Actual Cost (AC): $140,000

The project sponsor wants to know the projected final cost.

parts.question: What is the CPI? Round to two decimal places.
What is the SPI? Round to two decimal places.
Using EAC = BAC / CPI, what is the Estimate at Completion? Round to the nearest whole dollar.
parts.explanation: EAC = BAC / CPI = $250,000 / 0.89 ≈ $280,899. The project is forecasted to cost approximately $30,899 more than budgeted.

parts.question: What is the Estimate to Complete (ETC)? Use ETC = EAC - AC. Round to the nearest whole dollar.
parts.explanation: ETC = EAC - AC = $280,899 - $140,000 = $140,899. This is the estimated cost to complete the remaining work.

questions.explanation: This scenario chains EVM calculations: CPI → EAC → ETC. The sponsor learns the project is trending toward a ~$31,000 overrun and still needs approximately $141,000 to finish.

questions.scenario: You are planning the budget for a data center migration project. The cost estimates for all work packages total $320,000. The risk assessment identified several known risks, and you have allocated a 10% contingency reserve. The PMO requires a 5% management reserve on top of the project budget.

parts.question: What is the contingency reserve amount?
parts.explanation: Contingency reserve = $320,000 × 10% = $32,000. This covers known risks that have been identified and accepted.

parts.question: What is the cost baseline? (cost estimate + contingency reserve)
parts.explanation: Cost baseline = cost estimate + contingency reserve = $320,000 + $32,000 = $352,000. The cost baseline is used to measure cost performance.

parts.question: What is the management reserve amount? (5% of the cost baseline)
parts.explanation: Management reserve = $352,000 × 5% = $17,600. Management reserves cover 'unknown unknown' risks and unplanned scope changes.

parts.question: What is the total project budget? (cost baseline + management reserve)
parts.explanation: Project budget = cost baseline + management reserve = $352,000 + $17,600 = $369,600. The project budget is the total financial sum available for the project.

questions.explanation: The project budget is built in layers: cost estimate → add contingency reserve = cost baseline → add management reserve = project budget. Contingency reserves cover known risks. Management reserves cover unknown risks. The cost baseline (without management reserve) is used for EVM performance measurement.

questions.question: Match each EVM metric to its correct formula.
questions.explanation: These are the core EVM formulas. CV and SV measure variance in dollar terms (positive = favorable). CPI and SPI are ratios (> 1 = favorable, < 1 = unfavorable). VAC forecasts the final budget variance.

questions.question: Match each EVM indicator value to its correct interpretation.

pairs.right: Under budget — earning $1.15 per dollar spent
Behind schedule — only 85% of planned work completed
Ahead of schedule by $5,000 in earned value

questions.explanation: CPI > 1 = under budget. SPI < 1 = behind schedule. Negative CV = over budget. Positive SV = ahead of schedule. The key insight is that EV is always in the formula — it represents actual value delivered.

questions.question: A project manager calculates that the project's cost variance was caused by a vendor's one-time pricing error that has been corrected. Which EAC formula is MOST appropriate to forecast the final project cost?

options.text: EAC = BAC / CPI (assumes current CPI will continue)
EAC = AC + (BAC - EV) (assumes remaining work at budgeted rate)

questions.explanation: When the variance is atypical (a one-time event that won't recur), use EAC = AC + (BAC - EV). This assumes the remaining work will be completed at the original budgeted rate. Use BAC / CPI only when you expect the current CPI trend to continue.

questions.question: A project has a cost baseline of $200,000 and contingency reserves of $20,000. A risk event occurs and costs $8,000 from the contingency reserves. What is the new cost baseline?
questions.explanation: The cost baseline remains $200,000. Contingency reserves are part of the cost baseline, but spending them does not change the baseline itself. After the event, the contingency reserves decrease to $12,000, but the cost baseline figure used for performance measurement stays the same.
